content: hello friends and fellow crafters today we're going to do a hearth for the hub
we've been working on filling it out with items so let's go to the table and
we'll start with making the fireplace for our little Hubbell
to start the project I made the front of the hearth and that is just from a piece
of double thick cardboard so it is to actually it's an it's a half an inch
then the center piece was 2/3 of an inch and then the next edge was a half inch
so I cut that center piece out with an exacto knife it just made a little
easier to get those detailed cuts now for the face of the hearth I wanted to
do some texture on it so I used the stone texture that I made from my
texture cake molds and if you haven't seen that video scraftman umber 46 and
then i'll show you how to make those text that texture or you could just
paint it on with a sponge you wouldn't have to add this texture this is an
extra step so I cut up a piece that would cover the face and then I cut a
strip that would go around the top edge of the hearth once I had the hearth ax
covered in texture paper I cut a sheet magnet that was the size of the hearth
itself and then I attached that to the back of the hearth so that would be the
magnet what itself would be the backside of the hearth I wanted to simulate a
chimney on the back of the fireplace but I didn't want to have the full length of
the chimney I just want to kind of simulate that it was going up so what I
did was I cut a two inch long double thick cardboard piece that you see here
then I put a piece of cardstock on the top to cover up the corrugation and I
took my small glue gun and rimmed that cardstock to get an edge okay so then
the the body of the the chimney I wrapped it in the stone
texture paper that I've made from the cake molds and then I moved on from
there for the base of the fireplace I used a piece of thin cardboard and so
this is thinner than the it's about a half as thin as the regular cardboard
and I cut it it's a half an inch wide and I just used the fireplace hearth
itself to measure how long this base would be so now I want to cover this
with the texture paper that I made so you see I've got some lines on here and
I'm going to apply this to the base for the next step of the base I just cut out
the corners of the texture paper and then I was able to bend those edges over
so they'll cover the base there's a look at the base itself all covered now when
I do this kind of work I like to use the white glue the glue all because it gives
a nice bond and it's a lot less it's a lot less tricky than the than the hot
glue the hot glue is really good for certain applications but I find paper on
paper that the white glue works better here is a picture of the hearth that's
already been painted black to kind of differentiate it between the base and
glue to the base so I just use my small glue gun and I glued it right to the
base my next step was to simply spray everything black and then paint it so
here's the hearth I've painted with a pewter and then I used a dolphin gray to
pick out the highlights then I did the same thing with the chimney and for the
edge I just made sure that I didn't get in the simulated hole that I made with
the hot glue on the top edge I just painted the inside whole black and then
gray around the edge I had already applied a magnet to the back of the
fireplace so now I was going to apply 1/2
the chimney so it would stick to the back so I did was cut it out and it has
some adhesion on the back of the magnet but I find it doesn't really stay so I
usually glue it on with some white glue my finishing touch was to do my sponge
you guys have seen my sponge technique on the various projects and I dabbled on
pewter gray on both the magnet pieces on the hearth and the chimney and then I
add a little bit of dolphin gray to give some different color and the fireplace
is good to go here is a quick test picture how it's
